unnormalised: ## Return Policies: Because Nobody Wants a Lemon-Yellow Sari They Can't Wear to Diwali!
normalised: ## Return Policies: Because Nobody Wants a Lemon-Yellow Sari They Can't Wear to Diwali!

unnormalised: Let's face it, folks. Shopping, especially online shopping these days, is a bit of a gamble. You see that gorgeous sherwani on Flipkart, picture yourself looking like Shah Rukh Khan at cousin Radha's wedding, and BAM! It arrives looking like something your grandfather wore to a village panchayat meeting back in 1965. Hence, the noble (and often confusing) world of return policies.

unnormalised: Return policies are like that overprotective bua (aunt). They're there, ostensibly to protect you, but sometimes their rules make you want to scream into a pillow. Did you know some places in Chandni Chowk still operate on a "take it or leave it" policy? Talk about old-school!

unnormalised: Now, every online store and fancy boutique in Bandra has a different set of rules. Some offer a blissful "30-day, no questions asked" return policy, where you can basically return anything short of a used toothbrush. Others, well, let's just say their return policy is written in a font size so small, even Dr. Sharma, the eye specialist, needs a magnifying glass.
normalised: Now, every online store and fancy boutique in Bandra has a different set of rules. Some offer a blissful "thirty-day, no questions asked" return policy, where you can basically return anything short of a used toothbrush. Others, well, let's just say their return policy is written in a font size so small, even Doctor Sharma, the eye specialist, needs a magnifying glass.

unnormalised: Then there's the whole "original packaging" saga. You excitedly rip open the box, convinced your life will be changed by this new gadget from Amazon, only to discover it's the wrong shade of pink. Suddenly, you're frantically searching for the mangled cardboard and enough bubble wrap to insulate a 500 sq ft apartment in Mumbai.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on return shipping! Sometimes it's free, sometimes you pay Rs. 200, and sometimes you feel like you're being charged enough to ship the entire consignment to Kolkata.
normalised: And don't even get me started on return shipping! Sometimes it's free, sometimes you pay rupee two hundred, and sometimes you feel like you're being charged enough to ship the entire consignment to Kolkata.

unnormalised: So, before you click "add to cart" on that tempting deal from Myntra, do yourself a favor: read the fine print. Understand the return policy. Because ending up with a lemon-yellow sari you can't wear to Diwali is not just a fashion faux pas, it's a financial tragedy! Remember kids, caveat emptor (buyer beware) is still relevant, even in the age of 10-day return windows! And always keep that Flipkart invoice safe – tucked away with your Aadhar card and ration card, just in case.
